pli-tv-kd1:1.0.1: 1. The story at the Bodhi tree
pli-tv-kd1:1.0.2: Homage to the Buddha, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One
pli-tv-kd1:1.1.1: At one time, soon after his awakening, the Buddha was staying at Uruvelā on the bank of the river Nerañjara at the foot of a Bodhi tree.
pli-tv-kd1:1.1.2: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.1: Then, in the first part of the night, the Buddha reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.2: “Ignorance is a condition for intentional activities; intentional activities are a condition for consciousness; consciousness is a condition for name and form; name and form are a condition for the six sense spheres; the six sense spheres are a condition for contact; contact is a condition for feeling; feeling is a condition for craving; craving is a condition for grasping; grasping is a condition for existence; existence is a condition for birth; birth is a condition for old age and death, for grief, sorrow, pain, aversion, and distress to come to be.
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.3: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.4: “But with the complete fading away and end of ignorance comes the end of intentional activities; with the end of intentional activities comes the end of consciousness; with the end of consciousness comes the end of name and form; with the end of name and form comes the end of the six sense spheres; with the end of the six sense spheres comes the end of contact; with the end of contact comes the end of feeling; with the end of feeling comes the end of craving; with the end of craving comes the end of grasping; with the end of grasping comes the end of existence; with the end of existence comes the end of birth; with the end of birth comes the end of old age and death, and the end of sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and distress.
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.5: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.3.1: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
pli-tv-kd1:1.3.3: To the energetic brahmin who practices absorption,
pli-tv-kd1:1.3.4: Then all his doubts are dispelled,
pli-tv-kd1:1.3.5: Since he understands the natural order and its conditions.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.4.1: In the middle part of the night, the Buddha again reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:
pli-tv-kd1:1.4.2: “Ignorance is a condition for intentional activities; intentional activities are a condition for consciousness; consciousness is a condition for name and form …
pli-tv-kd1:1.4.3: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering. …
pli-tv-kd1:1.4.4: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.5.1: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
pli-tv-kd1:1.5.3: To the energetic brahmin who practices absorption,
pli-tv-kd1:1.5.4: Then all his doubts are dispelled,
pli-tv-kd1:1.5.5: Since he’s understood the end of the conditions.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.6.1: In the last part of the night, the Buddha again reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:
pli-tv-kd1:1.6.2: “Ignorance is a condition for intentional activities; intentional activities are a condition for consciousness; consciousness is a condition for name and form …
pli-tv-kd1:1.6.3: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering. …
pli-tv-kd1:1.6.4: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.1: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.3: To the energetic brahmin who practices absorption,
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.4: He defeats the army of the Lord of Death,
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.5: Like the sun shining in the sky.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.6: The story at the Bodhi tree is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:2.1.0: 2. The story at the goat-herd’s banyan tree
pli-tv-kd1:2.1.1: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the Bodhi tree to a goat-herd’s banyan tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:2.2.1: Then a conceited brahmin approached the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd1:2.2.5: “Good Gotama, how is one a brahmin? What are the things that make one a brahmin?”
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.1: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.2: “The brahmin who has shut out bad qualities,
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.3: Who is humble, free from flaws, and self-controlled,
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.4: Who has reached the end of knowledge and has lived the spiritual life—
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.5: Righteously, without being full of himself,
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.6: He may proclaim himself a brahmin.”
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.7: The story at the goat-herd’s banyan tree is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:3.1.0: 3. The story at the powder-puff tree
pli-tv-kd1:3.1.1: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the goat-herd’s banyan tree to a powder-puff tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:3.2.1: Just then an unseasonal storm was approaching, with seven days of rain, cold winds, and clouds.
pli-tv-kd1:3.2.2: Mucalinda, the dragon king, came out from his abode. And he encircled the body of the Buddha with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head, thinking,
pli-tv-kd1:3.2.3: “May the Buddha not be hot or cold, nor be touched by horseflies or mosquitoes, by the wind or the burning sun, or by creeping animals and insects.”
pli-tv-kd1:3.3.1: After seven days, when he knew the sky was clear, Mucalinda unraveled his coils from the Buddha’s body and transformed himself into a young brahmin. He then stood in front of the Buddha, venerating him with joined palms raised.
pli-tv-kd1:3.3.2: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.1: “Seclusion is bliss for the contented one,
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.2: For the one who sees the Truth that he has heard.
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.3: Kindness to the world is happiness,
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.4: For the one who is harmless to living beings.
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.5: Dispassion for the world is happiness,
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.6: For the one who overcomes sensuality.
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.7: But removing the conceit ʻI am’,
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.8: This, indeed, is the highest bliss.”
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.9: The story at the powder-puff tree is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:4.1.0: 4. The story at the ape-flower tree
pli-tv-kd1:4.1.1: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the powder-puff tree to an ape-flower tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.1: Just then the merchants Tapussa and Bhallika were traveling from Ukkala to that area.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.2: Then a god who was a former relative of theirs said to them,
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.3: “Sirs, a Buddha who has just attained awakening is staying at the foot of an ape-flower tree.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.4: Go to that Buddha and offer him baked goods and honey.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.5: That will be for your benefit and happiness for a long time.”
pli-tv-kd1:4.3.1: And they took baked goods and honey and approached the Buddha. They bowed down
pli-tv-kd1:4.3.3: “Venerable Sir, please accept the baked goods and honey from us. That will be to our benefit and happiness for a long time.”
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.3: In what should I receive the baked goods and honey?”
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.4: Then, reading the mind of the Buddha, the four great kings offered him four stone bowls from the four directions, saying,
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.5: “Here, Sir, please receive the baked goods and honey in these.”
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.6: After receiving the baked goods and honey in one of the valuable stone bowls, the Buddha ate them.
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.1: When Tapussa and Bhallika knew that the Buddha had finished his meal, they bowed down with their head at his feet, and said,
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.2: “Sir, we take refuge in the Buddha and the Teaching. Please accept us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.3: By means of the double refuge, they became the first lay followers in the world.
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.4: The story at the ape-flower tree is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:5.1.0: 5. The account of the supreme being’s request
pli-tv-kd1:5.1.1: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the ape-flower tree to a goat-herd’s banyan tree,
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.1: Then, while in seclusion, the Buddha thought this:
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.2: “I have discovered this profound truth, so hard to see, so hard to comprehend. It’s peaceful and sublime, subtle, beyond the intellect, and knowable only to the wise.
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.3: But human beings delight in holding on, find pleasure in holding on, rejoice in holding on,
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.4: and because of that it’s hard for them to see causal relationships, dependent origination.
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.5: This too is very hard for them to see: the stilling of all intentional activities, the giving up of all ownership, the stopping of craving, fading away, ending, extinguishment.
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.6: If I were to teach this truth, others would not understand, and that would be wearying and troublesome for me.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.1: And spontaneously, these verses never heard before occurred to the Buddha:
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.3: There’s no point in making it known.
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.4: For those overcome by sensual desire and ill will,
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.5: This truth is hard to understand.
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.6: Those who are excited by sensual desire,
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.7: Obstructed by a mass of darkness,
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.8: Won’t see what goes against the stream,
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.9: What’s subtle and refined, profound and hard to see.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.4.1: When the Buddha reflected like this, he inclined to inactivity, and not to teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:5.4.2: Just then the supreme being Sahampati read the mind of the Buddha. And he thought,
pli-tv-kd1:5.4.3: “The world is lost; it’s perished!—for the Buddha, perfected and fully awakened, inclines to inaction, and not to teaching.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.5.1: Then, just as a strong man might bend or stretch out his arm, so Sahampati disappeared from the world of supreme beings and appeared in front of the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd1:5.6.1: He put his upper robe over one shoulder, placed his right knee on the ground, raise his joined palms, and said,
pli-tv-kd1:5.6.3: There are beings with little dust in their eyes who are ruined because of not hearing the Teaching. There will be those who understand.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.1: This is what Sahampati said, and he added:
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.3: An impure teaching appeared, conceived by defiled people.
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.4: Open this door to the deathless!
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.5: Let them hear the Truth, discovered by the Pure One.
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.6: Just as one standing on a rocky mountain top
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.7: Would see the people all around,
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.9: Ascend the temple of the Truth.
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.10: Being rid of sorrow, look upon the people,
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.11: Sunk in grief, overcome by birth and old age.
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.13: Debtless One, Leader of travelers, go walking in the world.
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.15: There will be those who understand.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.8.1: Twice the Buddha repeated to Sahampati what he had thought,
pli-tv-kd1:5.8.4: But human beings delight in holding on, find pleasure in holding on, rejoice in holding on,
pli-tv-kd1:5.8.5: and because of that it’s hard for them to see causal relationships, dependent origination.
pli-tv-kd1:5.8.6: This too is very hard for them to see: the stilling of all intentional activities, the giving up of all ownership, the stopping of craving, fading away, ending, extinguishment.
pli-tv-kd1:5.9.1: and on both occasions Sahampati repeated his request.

pli-tv-kd1:5.10.1: The Buddha understood the request of that supreme being, and because he had compassion for the world, he surveyed the world with the eye of a Buddha.
pli-tv-kd1:5.11.1: He saw beings with little dust in their eyes and with much dust in their eyes, with sharp faculties and with dull faculties, with good qualities and with bad qualities, those easy to teach and those difficult to teach, and he even saw some who regarded the next world as dangerous and to be avoided.
pli-tv-kd1:5.11.2: It was just like a lotus pond with lotuses born and grown in water: some remain submerged in the water without rising out of it, others reach the surface of the water, and others still rise out of the water without being touched by it.
pli-tv-kd1:5.12.1: When he had seen this, the Buddha replied to Sahampati in verse:
pli-tv-kd1:5.12.2: “Open to them are the doors to the deathless;
pli-tv-kd1:5.12.3: May those who hear give rise to faith.
pli-tv-kd1:5.12.5: I did not speak the sublime and subtle Truth.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.13.2: “The Buddha has consented to teach.” He bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and disappeared right there.
pli-tv-kd1:5.13.3: The account of the supreme being’s request is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:6.1.6: Perhaps I should teach him first. He will understand this Teaching quickly.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.2.1: But an invisible god informed the Buddha, “Sir, Ālāra Kālāma died seven days ago,”
pli-tv-kd1:6.2.2: and the Buddha also knew this for himself.

pli-tv-kd1:6.6.1: Perhaps I should teach them first.
pli-tv-kd1:6.6.3: But where are they staying now?”
pli-tv-kd1:6.6.4: And with superhuman and purified clairvoyance, the Buddha saw that the group of five monks were staying near Benares, in the dear park at Isipatana.
pli-tv-kd1:6.6.5: Then, after staying at Uruvelā for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Benares.
pli-tv-kd1:6.7.1: The Ājīvaka ascetic Upaka saw the Buddha traveling between Gayā and the place of awakening. And he said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd1:6.7.2: “Sir, your faculties are clear and your skin is pure and bright.
pli-tv-kd1:6.7.3: Who have you gone forth under?
pli-tv-kd1:6.7.5: or whose teaching do you follow?”
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.1: The Buddha replied to Upaka in verse:
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.3: Abandoning all, I’m not soiled by anything.
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.4: Through my own insight, I’m freed by the ending of craving—
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.5: So who should I refer to as a teacher?

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.14: I’m going to the city of Kāsi,
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.15: To set rolling the wheel of the Teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.16: In this world immersed in darkness,
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.17: I’ll beat the drum of the deathless.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.9.6: Saying, “May it be so,” Upaka shook his head, chose the wrong road, and left.
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.1: The Buddha continued wandering toward the deer park at Isipatana near Benares. When he eventually arrived, he approached to the group of five monks.
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.3: the group of five made an agreement with one another:
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.4: “Here comes the ascetic Gotama, who has has given up his striving and returned to a life of abundance.
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.5: We shouldn’t bow down to him, stand up for him, or receive his bowl and robe,
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.6: but we should prepare a seat. If he wishes, he may sit down.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.1: But as the Buddha approached, the group of five monks was unable to keep their agreement.
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.2: One went to meet him to receive his bowl and robe, another prepared a seat, another set out water for washing the feet, yet another set out a foot-stool, and the last one put out a foot-scraper.
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.3: The Buddha sat down on the prepared seat
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.5: But they still addressed him by name and as “friend”.
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.1: The Buddha said to the group of five monks,
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.2: “Monks, don’t address the Buddha by name or as ʻfriend’.
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.3: Listen, I’m perfected and fully awakened. I have discovered the deathless. I will instruct you and teach you the Truth.
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.5: in this very life you will soon realize with your own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.6: for which people from good families rightly go forth from home to homelessness.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.13.2: “Friend Gotama, by practicing extreme austerities you didn’t gain any superhuman quality, any distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of noble ones. Since you have given up your striving and returned to a life of abundance, how could you now have achieved any of this?”
pli-tv-kd1:6.14.2: “I haven’t given up striving and returned to a life of abundance,”
pli-tv-kd1:6.14.3: and he repeated what he had said before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.16.2: “Do you remember me ever making such a statement?”
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.4: “Then listen. I’m perfected and fully awakened. I have discovered the deathless. I will instruct you and teach you the Truth.
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.6: in this very life you will soon realize with your own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.7: for which people from good families rightly go forth from home to homelessness.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.8: The Buddha was able to persuade the group of five monks.

pli-tv-kd1:6.17.5: By avoiding both these opposites, I have awakened to the middle path, which produces vision and knowledge, which leads to peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

pli-tv-kd1:6.19.3: In brief, the five aspects of existence affected by grasping are suffering.
pli-tv-kd1:6.20.1: And this is noble truth of the origin of suffering:
pli-tv-kd1:6.20.2: the craving that leads to rebirth, that comes with delight and sensual desire, ever delighting in this and that,
pli-tv-kd1:6.20.3: that is, craving for worldly pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for non-existence.
pli-tv-kd1:6.21.1: And this is noble truth of the end of suffering:
pli-tv-kd1:6.21.2: the full fading away and ending of that very craving; giving it up, relinquishing it, releasing it, letting it go.
pli-tv-kd1:6.22.1: And this is noble truth of the path leading to the end of suffering:
pli-tv-kd1:6.22.3: that is, right view, right aim, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right stillness.

pli-tv-kd1:6.27.1: So long as I had not fully purified my knowledge and vision according to reality of these four noble truths with their three stages and twelve characteristics, I didn’t claim the supreme full awakening in this world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, in this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and people.
pli-tv-kd1:6.28.1: But when I had fully purified my knowledge and vision according to reality of these four noble truths with their three stages and twelve characteristics, then I did claim the supreme full awakening in this world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, in this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and people.

pli-tv-kd1:14.1.0: 11. The account of a fine group of people
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Benares for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Uruvelā.
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.2: At a certain point he left the road, entered a forest grove, and sat down at the foot of a tree.
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.3: Just then a fine group of thirty friends and their wives were enjoying themselves in that forest grove.
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.4: Because one of them did not have a wife,
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.5: they had given him a prostitute.
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.6: While they were all carelessly enjoying themselves, that prostitute took that man’s possessions and ran away.
pli-tv-kd1:14.2.1: To help their friend, they all went searching for that woman. And as they walked about that forest grove, they saw the Buddha seated at the foot of a tree.
pli-tv-kd1:14.2.3: “Sir, have you by any chance seen a woman by herself?”
pli-tv-kd1:14.2.4: “But, young men, what use is a woman to you?”
pli-tv-kd1:14.2.5: They told him what had happened.

pli-tv-kd1:14.3.2: that you search for a woman, or that you search for yourselves?”
pli-tv-kd1:14.3.3: “It’s better for us to search for ourselves.”
pli-tv-kd1:14.3.4: “Well then, sit down, and I’ll give you a teaching.”
pli-tv-kd1:14.3.5: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” those friends bowed to the Buddha and sat down.

pli-tv-kd1:14.4.2: talk on generosity, talk on morality, talk on heaven; and he revealed the danger, degradation, and defilement in worldly pleasures, and the benefit of renunciation.

pli-tv-kd1:22.1.0: 13. The account of the meeting with Bimbisāra
pli-tv-kd1:22.1.1: After staying at Gayāsīsa for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward Rājagaha with that large sangha of one thousand monks, all of them previously dreadlocked ascetics.
pli-tv-kd1:22.1.2: When he eventually arrived at Rājagaha,

pli-tv-kd1:22.2.1: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha heard:
pli-tv-kd1:22.2.2: “Sir, the ascetic Gotama, the Sakyan, who has gone forth from the Sakyan clan, has arrived at Rājagaha and is staying in the cane grove at the Suppatiṭṭha Shrine.

pli-tv-kd1:22.2.4: “‘He is indeed a Master, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of tamable people, teacher of gods and humans, the Master, the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd1:22.2.5: With his own insight he has seen this world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, and he makes it known to others.
pli-tv-kd1:22.2.6: He has a Teaching that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end. It has a true goal and is well articulated. He sets out a perfectly complete and pure spiritual life.’
pli-tv-kd1:22.2.7: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

pli-tv-kd1:24.3.1: They then took those two hundred and fifty wanderers and went to the Bamboo Grove.
pli-tv-kd1:24.3.2: But the wanderer Sañcaya vomited warm blood right there.
pli-tv-kd1:24.3.3: When the Buddha saw Sāriputta and Moggallāna coming, he said to the monks,
pli-tv-kd1:24.3.4: “The two friends Kolita and Upatissa are coming.
pli-tv-kd1:24.3.5: They will be my most eminent disciples, an excellent pair.”
pli-tv-kd1:24.3.6: They had not even reached the Bamboo Grove,
pli-tv-kd1:24.3.7: Yet had a profound range of knowledge,
pli-tv-kd1:24.3.8: About the supreme end of ownership, about freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:24.3.12: They will be an excellent pair,
pli-tv-kd1:24.4.1: Sāriputta and Moggallāna approached the Buddha, bowed down with their heads at the Buddha’s feet, and said,
pli-tv-kd1:24.4.2: “Venerable Sir, we wish to receive the going forth in your presence; we wish to receive the full ordination.”
pli-tv-kd1:24.4.4: The Teaching is well-proclaimed. Practice the spiritual life to make a complete end of suffering.”
pli-tv-kd1:24.4.5: And that was the full ordination of those venerables.
pli-tv-kd1:24.5.0: 14.1 The going forth of those who were well-known
pli-tv-kd1:24.5.1: At that time many well-known Magadhans from good families were practicing the spiritual life under the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd1:24.5.3: “The ascetic Gotama is making us childless and he’s making widows out of us; he’s breaking up good families. Right now a thousand dreadlocked ascetics have gone forth because of him, and also these two hundred and fifty wanderers who were disciples of Sañcaya.
pli-tv-kd1:24.5.4: All these well-known Magadhans from good families are practicing the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama.”
pli-tv-kd1:24.5.5: And when they saw monks, they confronted them with this verse:
pli-tv-kd1:24.5.8: After leading away all of Sañcaya’s disciples,
pli-tv-kd1:24.5.9: Who will he lead away next?”
pli-tv-kd1:24.6.1: The monks heard the complaints of those people
pli-tv-kd1:24.6.2: and they told the Buddha what had happened. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and said,
pli-tv-kd1:24.6.3: “The complaining will soon stop; it will only last seven days.
pli-tv-kd1:24.6.4: And when people confront you like this,
pli-tv-kd1:24.6.9: you can confront them in return with this verse:
pli-tv-kd1:24.6.10: ʻIndeed, the Great Heroes, the Buddhas,
pli-tv-kd1:24.6.11: Lead by means of a good teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:24.6.12: When you understand this, what indignation can there be
pli-tv-kd1:24.7.1: Soon, when they had seen monks, people confronted them with this verse:
pli-tv-kd1:24.7.4: After leading away all of Sañcaya’s disciples,
pli-tv-kd1:24.7.5: Who will he lead away next?”
pli-tv-kd1:24.7.6: And the monks confronted them in return with this verse:
pli-tv-kd1:24.7.8: Lead by means of a good teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:24.7.9: When you understand this, what indignation can there be
pli-tv-kd1:24.7.11: People thought, “So it seems the Sakyan ascetics lead legitimately, not illegitimately.” And the complaining lasted seven days, and then it stopped.
pli-tv-kd1:24.7.12: The account of the going forth of Sāriputta and Moggallāna is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:25.1.0: 15. Discussion of the proper conduct toward the preceptor
pli-tv-kd1:25.1.1: At that time the monks did not have preceptors or teachers, and as a result they were not being instructed. While walking for almsfood, they were shabbily dressed and improper in appearance.
pli-tv-kd1:25.1.2: While people were eating, they held out their almsbowls to receive leftovers, even right over their food, whether it was staple food, non-staple food, delicacies, or drinks.
pli-tv-kd1:25.1.3: They ate bean curry and rice that they themselves had asked for,
pli-tv-kd1:25.1.4: and they were noisy in the dining hall.
pli-tv-kd1:25.2.2: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
pli-tv-kd1:25.2.5: They are just like brahmins at a brahminical meal.”
pli-tv-kd1:25.3.1: The monks heard the complaints of those people.
pli-tv-kd1:25.3.2: The monks of few desires who had a sense of conscience, who were contented, afraid of wrongdoing, and fond of the training, complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd1:25.4.3: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:25.4.4: “Is it true, monks, that monks act like this?”
pli-tv-kd1:25.5.2: “It’s not suitable for those foolish men, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
pli-tv-kd1:25.5.3: How can they act like this?
pli-tv-kd1:25.5.4: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it or increase the confidence of those who have it,
pli-tv-kd1:25.5.5: but it will hinder confidence in those without it, and it will cause some with confidence to change their minds.”
pli-tv-kd1:25.6.1: Then the Buddha spoke in many ways in dispraise of being difficult to support and maintain, in dispraise of great desires, discontent, socializing, and laziness; but he spoke in many ways in praise of being easy to support and maintain, of fewness of wishes, contentment, self-elimination, ascetic practices, serenity, reduction in things, and of being energetic. After giving a teaching on what is right and proper, he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:25.6.3: The preceptor should regard his student as a son and the student his preceptor as a father.
pli-tv-kd1:25.6.4: In this way they will respect, esteem, and be considerate toward each other, and they will grow and reach greatness on this spiritual path.
pli-tv-kd1:25.7.1: And a preceptor should be chosen like this:
pli-tv-kd1:25.7.2: After putting his upper robe over one shoulder, a student should pay respect at the feet of a potential preceptor. He should then squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say,
pli-tv-kd1:25.7.4: And he should repeat this a second
pli-tv-kd1:25.7.6: If the other makes it understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech: ‘Yes,’ or, ‘No problem,’ or, ‘It’s suitable,’ or, ‘It’s appropriate,’ or, ‘Carry on with inspiration’—then a preceptor has been chosen.
pli-tv-kd1:25.7.7: If the other doesn’t make it understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then a preceptor hasn’t been chosen.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.1: “And a student should conduct himself properly toward his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.3: After getting up at the appropriate time, the student should take off his sandals and put his upper robe over one shoulder. He should then give his preceptor a toothbrush and water for rinsing the mouth, and he should prepare a seat for him.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.4: If there is rice porridge, he should wash a vessel and bring the rice porridge to his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.5: When the preceptor has drunk the rice porridge, the student should give him water and receive the vessel, and holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.6: When the preceptor has gotten up, the student should put away the seat.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.7: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:25.9.1: If the preceptor wants to enter the village, the student should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return. He should give him a belt. He should put the upper robes together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, and then give them to him. He should wash his preceptor’s bowl and then give it to him while wet.
pli-tv-kd1:25.9.2: If the preceptor wants an attendant, the student should put on his sarong evenly all around, covering the navel and the knees. He should put on a belt. Putting the upper robes together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, he should put them on and fasten the toggle. After washing his bowl, he should take it with him and be his preceptor’s attendant.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.1: He shouldn’t walk too far behind his preceptor or too close to him. He should receive the contents of his bowl.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.2: He shouldn’t interrupt his preceptor when he’s speaking.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.3: But if the preceptor’s speech is bordering on an offense, he should stop him.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.4: When returning, the student should go first to prepare a seat and to set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should go out to meet the preceptor to receive his bowl and robe. He should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.5: If the robe is moist, he should sun it for a short while, but he shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.6: He should fold the robe, offsetting the edges by seven centimeters,
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.7: so that the fold doesn’t become worn.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.8: He should place the belt in the fold.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.9: If there is almsfood and his preceptor wants to eat, the student should give him water and then the almsfood.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.1: He should ask his preceptor if he wants water to drink.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.2: When the preceptor has eaten, the student should give him water and receive the bowl, and holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it. He should then dry it and sun it for a short while, but he shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.3: The student should put away the robe and bowl.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.4: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.5: He should not put away the bowl on the bare ground.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.6: When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe-rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.7: When the preceptor has gotten up, the student should put away the seat and also the foot-stool, the foot-scraper, and the water for washing the feet.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.8: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.1: “If the preceptor wants to bathe, the student should prepare a bath.
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.2: If he wants a cold bath, he should prepare that;
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.3: if he wants a hot bath, he should prepare that.
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.4: If the preceptor wants to use the sauna, the student should knead bath powder, moisten the clay, take the sauna stool, and follow behind his preceptor. After giving the preceptor the sauna stool, receiving his robe, and putting it aside, he should give him the bath powder and the clay.
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.5: If he’s able, he should enter the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.6: When entering the sauna, he should smear his face with clay, cover himself in front and behind, and then enter the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.1: He shouldn’t sit encroaching on the senior monks,
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.2: and he shouldn’t block the junior monks from getting a seat.
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.3: While in the sauna, he should do services for his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.4: When leaving the sauna, he should take the sauna stool, cover himself in front and behind, and then leave the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.5: He should also do services for his preceptor in the water.
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.6: When he has bathed, he should be the first to come out of the water. He should dry himself and put on his sarong. He should then wipe the water off his preceptor’s body, and he should give him his sarong and then his upper robe. Taking the sauna stool, he should be the first to return. He should prepare a seat, as well as set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should ask his preceptor if he wants water to drink.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.1: If the preceptor wants him to recite, he should do so.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.2: If the preceptor wants to question him, he should be questioned.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.3: “If the dwelling where the preceptor is staying is dirty, the student should clean it if he’s able.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.4: When he’s cleaning the dwelling, he should first take out the bowl and robe and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.5: He should take out the sitting mat and the sheet and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.6: He should take out the mattress and the pillow and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.1: Holding the bed low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.2: Holding the bench low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.3: He should take out the bed supports and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.4: He should take out the spittoon and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.5: He should take out the leaning board and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.6: After taking note of where it’s placed, he should take out the floor cover and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.7: If the dwelling has cobwebs, he should first remove them from the ceiling cloth, and he should then wipe the windows and the corners of the room.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.8: If the walls have been treated with red ocher and they’re moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the walls.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.9: If the floor has been treated with black and it’s moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the floor.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.10: If the floor is untreated, he should sprinkle it with water and then sweep it,
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.11: while trying to avoid stirring up dust.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.12: He should look out for any trash and discard it.
pli-tv-kd1:25.16.1: He should sun the floor cover, clean it, beat it, bring it back inside, and put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:25.16.2: He should sun the bed supports, wipe them, bring them back inside, and place them in the same position as before.
pli-tv-kd1:25.16.3: He should sun the bed, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:25.16.4: He should sun the bench, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:25.16.5: He should sun the mattress and the pillow, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
pli-tv-kd1:25.16.6: He should sun the sitting mat and the sheet, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
pli-tv-kd1:25.16.7: He should sun the spittoon, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd1:25.16.8: He should sun the leaning board, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd1:25.17.1: He should put away the bowl and robe.
pli-tv-kd1:25.17.2: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd1:25.17.3: He should not put away the bowl on the bare ground.
pli-tv-kd1:25.17.4: When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe-rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.
pli-tv-kd1:25.18.1: If dusty winds are blowing from the east, he should close the windows on the eastern side.
pli-tv-kd1:25.18.2: If dusty winds are blowing from the west, he should close the windows on the western side.
pli-tv-kd1:25.18.3: If dusty winds are blowing from the north, he should close the windows on the northern side.
pli-tv-kd1:25.18.4: If dusty winds are blowing from the south, he should close the windows on the southern side.
pli-tv-kd1:25.18.5: If the weather is cold, he should open the windows during the day and close them at night.
pli-tv-kd1:25.18.6: If the weather is hot, he should close the windows during the day and open them at night.
pli-tv-kd1:25.19.1: If the precincts are dirty, he should sweep them.
pli-tv-kd1:25.19.2: If the gateway is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:25.19.3: If the assembly hall is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:25.19.4: If the water-boiling shed is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:25.19.5: If the restroom is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:25.19.6: If there is no water for drinking, he should set it out.
pli-tv-kd1:25.19.7: If there is no water for washing, he should set it out.
pli-tv-kd1:25.19.8: If there is no water in the rinsing pot, he should fill it.
pli-tv-kd1:25.20.1: “If the preceptor becomes discontent, the student should send him away or have him sent away, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:25.20.2: If the preceptor becomes anxious, the student should dispel it or have it dispelled, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:25.20.3: If the preceptor has a wrong view, the student should make him give it up or get someone else to do it, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:25.21.1: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves probation,
pli-tv-kd1:25.21.2: the student should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:25.21.3: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be sent back to the beginning,
pli-tv-kd1:25.21.4: the student should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:25.21.5: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be given the trial period,
pli-tv-kd1:25.21.6: the student should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:25.21.7: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves rehabilitation,
pli-tv-kd1:25.21.8: the student should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:25.22.1: If the Sangha wants to do a legal procedure against his preceptor—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd1:25.22.2: the student should make an effort to stop it or to reduce the penalty.
pli-tv-kd1:25.22.3: But if the Sangha has already done a legal procedure against his preceptor—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd1:25.22.4: the student should help the preceptor conduct himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and try for the Sangha to lift that procedure.
pli-tv-kd1:25.23.1: “If the preceptor’s robe needs washing, the student should do it himself,
pli-tv-kd1:25.23.2: he should make an effort or to have it done.
pli-tv-kd1:25.23.3: If the preceptor needs a robe, the student should make one himself,
pli-tv-kd1:25.23.4: or he should make an effort to have one made.
pli-tv-kd1:25.23.5: If the preceptor needs dye, the student should make it himself,
pli-tv-kd1:25.23.6: or he should make an effort to have it made.
pli-tv-kd1:25.23.7: If the preceptor’s robe needs dyeing, the student should do it himself,
pli-tv-kd1:25.23.8: or he should make an effort to have it done.
pli-tv-kd1:25.23.9: When he’s dyeing the robe, he should carefully and repeatedly turn it over, and he shouldn’t go away while it’s still dripping.
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.1: Without asking permission of his preceptor, he shouldn’t do any of the following: give away or receive a bowl;
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.2: give away or receive a robe;
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.3: give away or receive a requisite;
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.4: cut anyone’s hair or have it cut;
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.5: do work for anyone or have work done by anyone;
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.6: do a service for anyone or have a service done by anyone;
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.7: be the attendant monk for anyone or take anyone as his attendant monk;
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.8: bring back almsfood for anyone or have almsfood brought back by anyone;
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.12: If his preceptor is sick, he should nurse him for as long as he lives,
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.13: or he should wait until he has recovered.”
pli-tv-kd1:25.24.14: The proper conduct toward the preceptor is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:26.1.1: “And a preceptor should conduct himself properly toward his student.
pli-tv-kd1:26.1.3: A preceptor should help and take care of his student through recitation, questioning, and instruction.
pli-tv-kd1:26.1.4: If the preceptor has a bowl, but not the student, the preceptor should give it to him,

pli-tv-kd1:26.1.6: If the preceptor has a robe, but not the student, the preceptor should give it to him,
pli-tv-kd1:26.1.7: or he should make an effort to get him one.
pli-tv-kd1:26.1.8: If the preceptor has a requisite, but not the student, the preceptor should give it to him,
pli-tv-kd1:26.1.9: or he should make an effort to get him one.
pli-tv-kd1:26.2.1: If the student is sick, the preceptor should get up at the appropriate time, and he should give his student a toothbrush and water for rinsing the mouth, and he should prepare a seat for him.
