pli-tv-kd1:26.4.8: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:26.5.1: “If the student wants to bathe, the preceptor should prepare the bath.
pli-tv-kd1:26.5.2: If he wants a cold bath, he should prepare that;
pli-tv-kd1:26.5.3: if he wants a hot bath, he should prepare that.
pli-tv-kd1:26.5.4: If the student wants to use the sauna, the preceptor should knead bath powder, moisten the clay, take the sauna stool, and go to the sauna. After giving the student the sauna stool, receiving his robe, and putting it aside, he should give him the bath powder and the clay.
pli-tv-kd1:26.5.5: If he’s able, he should enter the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:26.5.6: When entering the sauna, he should smear his face with clay, cover himself in front and behind, and then enter the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:26.6.1: He shouldn’t sit encroaching on the senior monks,
pli-tv-kd1:26.6.2: and he shouldn’t block the junior monks from getting a seat.
pli-tv-kd1:26.6.3: While in the sauna, he should do services for his student.
pli-tv-kd1:26.6.4: When leaving the sauna, he should take the sauna stool, cover himself in front and behind, and then leave the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:26.6.5: The preceptor should also do services for his student in the water.
pli-tv-kd1:26.6.6: When the preceptor has bathed, he should be the first to come out of the water. He should dry himself and put on his sarong. He should then wipe the water off his student’s body, and he should give him his sarong and then his upper robe.
pli-tv-kd1:26.6.7: Taking the sauna stool, he should be the first to return. He should should prepare a seat, as well as set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet.
pli-tv-kd1:26.6.8: He should ask his student if he wants water to drink.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.1: “If the dwelling where the student is staying is dirty, the preceptor should clean it if he’s able.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.2: When he’s cleaning the dwelling, he should first take out the bowl and robe and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.3: He should take out the sitting mat and the sheet and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.4: He should take out the mattress and the pillow and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.5: Holding the bed low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.6: Holding the bench low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.7: He should take out the bed supports and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.8: He should take out the spittoon and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.9: He should take out the leaning board and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.10: After taking note of where it’s placed, he should take out the floor cover and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.11: If the dwelling has cobwebs, he should first remove them from the ceiling cloth, and he should then wipe the windows and the corners of the room.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.12: If the walls have been treated with red ocher and they’re moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the walls.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.13: If the floor has been treated with black and it’s moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the floor.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.14: If the floor is untreated, he should sprinkle it with water and then sweep it,
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.15: while trying to avoid stirring up dust.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.16: He should look out for any trash and discard it.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.17: He should sun the floor cover, clean it, beat it, bring it back inside, and put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.18: He should sun the bed supports, wipe them, bring them back inside, and place them in the same position as before.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.19: He should sun the bed, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.20: He should sun the bench, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.21: He should sun the mattress and the pillow, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.22: He should sun the sitting mat and the sheet, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.23: He should sun the spittoon, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.24: He should sun the leaning board, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.25: He should put away the bowl and robe.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.26: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.27: He should not put away the bowl on the bare ground.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.28: When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe-rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.29: If dusty winds are blowing from the east, he should close the windows on the eastern side.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.30: If dusty winds are blowing from the west, he should close the windows on the western side.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.31: If dusty winds are blowing from the north, he should close the windows on the northern side.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.32: If dusty winds are blowing from the south, he should close the windows on the southern side.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.33: If the weather is cold, he should open the windows during the day and close them at night.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.34: If the weather is hot, he should close the windows during the day and open them at night.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.35: If the precincts are dirty, he should sweep them.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.36: If the gateway is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.37: If the assembly hall is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.38: If the water-boiling shed is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.39: If the restroom is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.40: If there is no water for drinking, he should set it out.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.41: If there is no water for washing, he should set it out.
pli-tv-kd1:26.7.42: If there is no water in the rinsing pot, he should fill it.
pli-tv-kd1:26.8.1: “If the student becomes discontent, the preceptor should send him away or have him sent away, or he should give him a teaching
pli-tv-kd1:26.8.2: If the student becomes anxious, the preceptor should dispel it or have it dispelled, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:26.8.3: If the student has a wrong view, the preceptor should make him give it up or get someone else to do it, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:26.9.1: If the student has committed a heavy offense and deserves probation,
pli-tv-kd1:26.9.2: the preceptor should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:26.9.3: If the student has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be sent back to the beginning,
pli-tv-kd1:26.9.4: the preceptor should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:26.9.5: If the student has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be given the trial period,
pli-tv-kd1:26.9.6: the preceptor should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:26.9.7: If the student has committed a heavy offense and deserves rehabilitation,
pli-tv-kd1:26.9.8: the preceptor should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:26.10.1: If the Sangha wants to do a legal procedure against his student—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd1:26.10.2: the preceptor should make an effort to stop it or to reduce the penalty.
pli-tv-kd1:26.10.3: But if the Sangha has already done a legal procedure against his student—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd1:26.10.4: the preceptor should help the student conduct himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and try for the Sangha to lift that procedure.
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.1: “If the student’s robe needs washing, the preceptor should show him how to do it,
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.2: or he should make an effort to have it done.
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.3: If the student needs a robe, the preceptor should show him how to make one,
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.4: or he should make an effort to have one made.
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.5: If the student needs dye, the preceptor should show him how to make it,
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.6: or he should make an effort to have it made.
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.7: If the student’s robe needs dyeing, the preceptor should show him how to do it,
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.8: or he should make an effort to have it done.
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.9: When he’s dyeing the robe, he should carefully and repeatedly turn it over,
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.10: and he shouldn’t go away while it’s still dripping.
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.11: If his student is sick, he should nurse him for as long as he lives, or he should wait until he has recovered.”
pli-tv-kd1:26.11.12: The proper conduct toward a student is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:27.1.1: On a later occasion the students did not conduct themselves properly toward their preceptors.
pli-tv-kd1:27.1.2: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd1:27.1.3: “How can students not conduct themselves properly toward their preceptors?”
pli-tv-kd1:27.1.4: They told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:27.1.5: “Is it true, monks, that students are acting like this?”
pli-tv-kd1:27.1.8: “… How can students not conduct themselves properly toward their preceptors?” …
pli-tv-kd1:27.1.10: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:27.1.11: “A student should conduct himself properly toward his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:27.1.12: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:27.2.1: They still did not conduct themselves properly.
pli-tv-kd1:27.2.3: “You should dismiss one who doesn’t conduct himself properly.
pli-tv-kd1:27.2.4: And this is how he should be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:27.2.5: If the preceptor makes it understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech: ʻI dismiss you,’ or, ʻDon’t come back here,’ or, ʻRemove your bowl and robe,’ or, ʻYou shouldn’t attend on me’—then the student has been dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:27.2.6: If he doesn’t make it understood by body, speech, or by body and speech, then the student hasn’t been dismissed.”
pli-tv-kd1:27.3.1: Students who had been dismissed did not ask for forgiveness.
pli-tv-kd1:27.3.4: They still did not ask for forgiveness.
pli-tv-kd1:27.3.5: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:27.3.6: “One who has been dismissed should ask for forgiveness.
pli-tv-kd1:27.3.7: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:27.4.1: Preceptors who were asked for forgiveness did not forgive.
pli-tv-kd1:27.4.5: The students left, disrobed, and joined the ascetics of other religions.
pli-tv-kd1:27.4.6: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:27.4.7: “When asked for forgiveness, you should forgive.
pli-tv-kd1:27.4.8: If you don’t, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:27.5.1: Preceptors dismissed students who were conducting themselves properly and did not dismiss those who were not.
pli-tv-kd1:27.5.2: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:27.5.3: “You should not dismiss someone who is conducting himself properly.
pli-tv-kd1:27.5.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:27.5.5: And you should dismiss someone who isn’t conducting himself properly.
pli-tv-kd1:27.5.6: If you don’t, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:27.6.1: “If a student has five qualities, he should be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:27.6.2: He doesn’t have much affection for his preceptor; he doesn’t have much confidence in his preceptor; he doesn’t have a strong sense of conscience in regard to his preceptor; he doesn’t have much respect for his preceptor; he hasn’t developed his mind much under his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:27.6.4: If a student has five qualities, he shouldn’t be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:27.6.5: He has much affection for his preceptor; he has much confidence in his preceptor; he has strong sense of conscience in regard to his preceptor; he has much respect for his preceptor; he has developed his mind much under his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:27.7.1: If a student has five qualities, he deserves to be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:27.7.2: He doesn’t have much affection for his preceptor; he doesn’t have much confidence in his preceptor; he doesn’t have a strong sense of conscience in regard to his preceptor; he doesn’t have much respect for his preceptor; he hasn’t developed his mind much under his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:27.7.4: If a student has five qualities, he doesn’t deserve to be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:27.7.5: He has much affection for his preceptor; he has much confidence in his preceptor; he has a strong sense of conscience in regard to his preceptor; he has much respect for his preceptor; he has developed his mind much under his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:27.8.1: If a student has five qualities, the preceptor is at fault if he doesn’t dismiss him, but he’s not at fault if he dismisses him.
pli-tv-kd1:27.8.2: The student doesn’t have much affection for his preceptor; he doesn’t have much confidence in his preceptor; he doesn’t have a strong sense of conscience in regard to his preceptor; he doesn’t have much respect for his preceptor; he hasn’t developed his mind much under his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:27.8.4: If a student has five qualities, the preceptor is at fault if he dismisses him, but he’s not at fault if he doesn’t dismiss him.
pli-tv-kd1:27.8.5: The student has much affection for his preceptor; he has much confidence in his preceptor; he has a strong sense of conscience in regard to his preceptor; he has much respect for his preceptor; he has developed his mind much under his preceptor.”
pli-tv-kd1:28.1.1: On one occasion a brahmin approached the monks and asked for the going forth,
pli-tv-kd1:28.1.3: As a result, he became thin, haggard, and pale, his veins protruding all over his limbs.
pli-tv-kd1:28.1.4: The Buddha saw him, and he asked the monks,
pli-tv-kd1:28.1.5: “Why is that brahmin looking so sickly?”
pli-tv-kd1:28.1.6: And they told him what had happened.
pli-tv-kd1:28.2.2: “Does anyone remember any act of service from that brahmin?”
pli-tv-kd1:28.2.6: “While I was walking for almsfood here in Rājagaha, that brahmin gave a ladleful of food.”
pli-tv-kd1:28.3.1: “Good, good, Sāriputta, superior people have gratitude.
pli-tv-kd1:28.3.2: Well then, Sāriputta, give that brahmin the going forth and the full ordination.”
pli-tv-kd1:28.3.4: The Buddha then gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:28.3.5: “From today I rescind the full ordination of going for refuge three times.
pli-tv-kd1:28.4.1: Instead you should give the full ordination through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements.
pli-tv-kd1:28.4.2: And the ordination should be done like this.
pli-tv-kd1:28.4.3: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd1:28.4.4: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd1:28.4.5: So-and-so wants the full ordination with Venerable so-and-so.
pli-tv-kd1:28.4.6: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should give the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.1: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.2: So-and-so wants the full ordination with Venerable so-and-so.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.3: The Sangha gives the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.4: Any monk who approves of giving the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.5: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.6: For the second time I speak on this matter.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.7: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.8: So-and-so wants the full ordination with Venerable so-and-so.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.9: The Sangha gives the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.10: Any monk who approves of giving the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd1:28.5.11: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd1:28.6.1: For the third time I speak on this matter.
pli-tv-kd1:28.6.2: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd1:28.6.3: So-and-so wants the full ordination with Venerable so-and-so.
pli-tv-kd1:28.6.4: The Sangha gives the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:28.6.5: Any monk who approves of giving the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd1:28.6.6: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd1:28.6.7: The Sangha has given the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:28.6.8: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd1:29.1.1: On a later occasion, a monk misbehaved immediately after his full ordination.
pli-tv-kd1:29.1.3: “Please don’t do that; it’s not allowable.”
pli-tv-kd1:29.1.5: “But I didn’t ask you to ordain me.
pli-tv-kd1:29.1.6: Why did you ordain me without being asked?”
pli-tv-kd1:29.1.7: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:29.1.8: “You should not give the full ordination to someone without being asked.
pli-tv-kd1:29.1.9: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:29.1.10: I allow you to give the full ordination to someone when you have been asked.
pli-tv-kd1:29.2.1: And you should be asked like this.
pli-tv-kd1:29.2.2: After approaching the Sangha, the one who wants the full ordination should put his upper robe over one shoulder and pay respect at the feet of the monks. He should then squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:
pli-tv-kd1:29.2.3: ‘Venerables, I ask the Sangha for the full ordination. May the Sangha lift me up out of compassion.’
pli-tv-kd1:29.2.4: And he should ask a second
pli-tv-kd1:29.3.1: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd1:29.3.2: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd1:29.3.3: So-and-so wants the full ordination with Venerable so-and-so.
pli-tv-kd1:29.3.4: So-and-so is asking the Sangha for the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd1:29.3.5: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should give the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:29.4.1: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd1:29.4.2: So-and-so wants the full ordination with Venerable so-and-so.
pli-tv-kd1:29.4.3: So-and-so is asking the Sangha for the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd1:29.4.4: The Sangha gives the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:29.4.5: Any monk who approves of giving the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd1:29.4.6: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd1:29.4.7: For the second time I speak on this matter. …
pli-tv-kd1:29.4.8: For the third time I speak on this matter. …
pli-tv-kd1:29.4.9: The Sangha has given the full ordination to so-and-so with so-and-so as his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:29.4.10: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd1:30.1.1: At that time in Rājagaha, there was a succession of fine meals.
pli-tv-kd1:30.1.3: “These Sakyan ascetics have pleasant habits and a happy life. After eating nice food, they sleep in beds sheltered from the wind.
pli-tv-kd1:30.1.4: Let me go forth with the Sakyan ascetics.”
pli-tv-kd1:30.1.5: Then that brahmin approached the monks and asked for the going forth.
pli-tv-kd1:30.1.6: The monks gave him the going forth and the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd1:30.2.1: When he had gone forth, that succession of meals came to a stop.
pli-tv-kd1:30.2.5: “I didn’t go forth to walk for almsfood.
pli-tv-kd1:30.2.6: If you give me some, I’ll eat it. If not, I’ll disrobe.”
pli-tv-kd1:30.2.7: “But did you go forth for the sake of your stomach?”
pli-tv-kd1:30.3.1: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-kd1:30.3.2: “How can a monk go forth on this well-proclaimed spiritual path for the sake of his stomach?”
pli-tv-kd1:30.3.3: They told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned that monk:
pli-tv-kd1:30.3.4: “Is it true, monk, that you went forth for the sake of our stomach?”
pli-tv-kd1:30.3.7: “… Foolish man, how can you go forth on this well-proclaimed spiritual path for the sake of your stomach?
pli-tv-kd1:30.3.8: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it or increase the confidence of those who have it …” …
pli-tv-kd1:30.3.10: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.1: “When you are giving the full ordination, you should point out the four supports:
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.2: One gone forth is supported by almsfood. You should persevere with this for life.
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.3: These are the extra material supports:
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.4: a meal for the Sangha, a meal for designated monks, an invitational meal, a meal for which lots are drawn, a half-monthly meal, a meal on the observance day, and a meal on the day after the observance day.
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.5: One gone forth is supported by rag-robes. You should persevere with this for life.
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.6: These are the extra material supports:
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.7: linen, cotton, silk, wool, sunn hemp, and hemp.
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.8: One gone forth is supported by the foot of a tree as resting place. You should persevere with this for life.
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.9: These are the extra material supports:
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.10: a dwelling, a stilt house, and a cave.
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.11: One gone forth is supported by medicine of fermented urine. You should persevere with this for life.
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.12: These are the extra material supports:
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.13: ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup.”
pli-tv-kd1:30.4.14: The fifth section for recitation on the proper conduct toward the preceptor is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:31.1.0: 18. Discussion of the proper conduct toward a teacher
pli-tv-kd1:31.1.1: Soon afterwards a young brahmin approached the monks and asked for the going forth.
pli-tv-kd1:31.1.2: The monks told him about the four supports.
pli-tv-kd1:31.1.4: “Venerables, if you had told me about this after my going forth, I would have been fine.
pli-tv-kd1:31.1.5: But now I won’t go forth,
pli-tv-kd1:31.1.6: for these supports are disgusting and repulsive to me.”
pli-tv-kd1:31.1.7: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:31.1.8: “You should not point out the four supports beforehand.
pli-tv-kd1:31.1.9: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:31.1.10: You should point out the supports immediately after the full ordination.”
pli-tv-kd1:31.2.1: At that time the monks gave the full ordination in groups of two and three.
pli-tv-kd1:31.2.2: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:31.2.3: “You should not give the full ordination in groups of less than ten.
pli-tv-kd1:31.2.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:31.2.5: You should give the full ordination in groups of ten or more than ten.”
pli-tv-kd1:31.3.1: At that time monks who only had one or two years of seniority gave the full ordination,
pli-tv-kd1:31.3.2: one of whom was Venerable Upasena of Vaṅganta.
pli-tv-kd1:31.3.3: After completing the rainy-season residence, he had two years of seniority and his student one. Taking his student, he then went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd1:31.3.4: Since it is the custom for Buddhas to greet newly arrived monks,
pli-tv-kd1:31.4.2: “I hope you’re keeping well, monk, I hope you’re comfortable;
pli-tv-kd1:31.4.3: I hope you’re not tired from traveling.”
pli-tv-kd1:31.4.4: “I’m keeping well, Venerable Sir, I’m comfortable,
pli-tv-kd1:31.4.5: and I’m not tired from traveling.”
pli-tv-kd1:31.4.6: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not; they know the right time to ask and the right time not to ask.
pli-tv-kd1:31.4.7: Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, not when it is unbeneficial,
pli-tv-kd1:31.4.8: for Buddhas are incapable of doing what is unbeneficial.
pli-tv-kd1:31.4.9: Buddhas question the monks for two reasons: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.
pli-tv-kd1:31.5.1: The Buddha said to Upasena, “How long have you been a monk?”
pli-tv-kd1:31.5.8: “It’s not suitable, foolish man, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
pli-tv-kd1:31.5.9: How can you, who should be taught and instructed by others, think to teach and instruct another?
pli-tv-kd1:31.5.10: You have turned to abundance too readily, that is, by forming a group.
pli-tv-kd1:31.5.11: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it or increase the confidence of those who have it …” …
pli-tv-kd1:31.5.13: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:31.5.14: “You should not give the full ordination if you have less than ten years of seniority.
pli-tv-kd1:31.5.15: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:31.5.16: I allow you to give the full ordination if you have ten or more years of seniority.”
pli-tv-kd1:31.6.2: when they had ten years of seniority,
pli-tv-kd1:31.6.3: ignorant and incompetent monks gave the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd1:31.6.4: As a result there were ignorant preceptors with knowledgeable students,
pli-tv-kd1:31.6.8: A monk who was formerly an ascetic of another religion refuted his preceptor, even though he had been legitimately corrected by him. He then returned to that religious community.
pli-tv-kd1:31.7.1: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd1:31.7.2: “How can ignorant and incompetent monks give the full ordination just because they have ten years of seniority?
pli-tv-kd1:31.7.3: There are ignorant preceptors with knowledgeable students, incompetent preceptors with competent students, uneducated preceptors with learned students, stupid preceptors with clever students.”
pli-tv-kd1:31.7.4: They told the Buddha. He said,
pli-tv-kd1:31.7.5: “Is it true, monks, that this is happening?”
pli-tv-kd1:31.8.2: “How can those foolish men give the full ordination just because they have ten years of seniority?
pli-tv-kd1:31.8.4: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-kd1:31.8.6: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:31.8.7: “An ignorant and incompetent monk should not give the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd1:31.8.8: If he does, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:31.8.9: I allow a competent and capable monk to give the full ordination, if he has ten or more years of seniority.”
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.1: At that time there were preceptors who left, disrobed, died, or joined another faction, and as a consequence their students were not being instructed.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.2: While walking for almsfood, they were shabbily dressed and improper in appearance.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.3: While people were eating, they held out their almsbowls to receive leftovers, even right over their food, whether it was staple food, non-staple food, delicacies, or drinks.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.4: They ate bean curry and rice that they themselves had asked for,
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.5: and they were noisy in the dining hall.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.7: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.10: They are just like brahmins at a brahminical meal.”
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.11: The monks heard the complaints of those people. …
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.15: after rebuking them, the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.17: The teacher should regard his pupil as a son and the pupil his teacher as a father.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.18: In this way they will respect, esteem, and be considerate toward each other, and they will grow and reach greatness on this spiritual path.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.19: You should live with formal support for ten years. And I allow a monk of ten years’ seniority to give such support.
pli-tv-kd1:32.2.1: And a teacher should be chosen like this:
pli-tv-kd1:32.2.2: After putting his upper robe over one shoulder, a pupil should pay respect at the feet of a potential teacher. He should then squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say,
pli-tv-kd1:32.2.3: ‘Venerable, please be my teacher; I wish to live with formal support from you.’
pli-tv-kd1:32.2.4: And he should repeat this a second
pli-tv-kd1:32.2.6: If the other makes it understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech: ‘Yes,’ or, ‘No problem,’ or, ‘It’s suitable,’ or, ‘It’s appropriate,’ or, ‘Carry on with inspiration’—then a teacher has been chosen.
pli-tv-kd1:32.2.7: If the other doesn’t make it understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then a teacher hasn’t been chosen.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.1: “A pupil should conduct himself properly toward his teacher.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.3: After getting up at the appropriate time, the pupil should take off his sandals, and put his upper robe over one shoulder. He should then give his teacher a toothbrush and water for rinsing the mouth, and he should prepare a seat for him.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.4: If there is rice porridge, he should wash a vessel and bring the rice porridge to his teacher.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.5: When the teacher has drunk the rice porridge, the pupil should give him water and receive the vessel, and holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.6: When the teacher has gotten up, the pupil should put away the seat.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.7: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.8: If the teacher wants to enter the village, the pupil should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return. He should give him a belt. He should put the upper robes together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, and then give them to him. He should wash his teacher’s bowl and then give it to him while wet.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.9: If the teacher wants an attendant, the pupil should put on his sarong evenly all around, covering the navel and the knees. He should put on a belt. Putting the upper robes together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, he should put them on and fasten the toggle. After washing his bowl, he should take it with him and be his teacher’s attendant.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.10: He shouldn’t walk too far behind his teacher or too close to him. He should receive the contents of his bowl.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.11: He shouldn’t interrupt his teacher when he’s speaking.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.12: But if the teacher’s speech is bordering on an offense, he should stop him.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.13: When returning, the pupil should go first to prepare a seat and to set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should go out to meet the teacher to receive his bowl and robe. He should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.14: If the robe is moist, he should sun it for a short while, but he shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.16: offsetting the edges by seven centimeters,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.17: so that the fold doesn’t become worn.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.18: He should place the belt in the fold.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.19: If there is almsfood and his teacher wants to eat, the pupil should give him water and then the almsfood.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.20: He should ask his teacher if he wants water to drink.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.21: When the teacher has eaten, the pupil should give him water and receive the bowl, and holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it. He should then dry it and sun it for a short while, but he shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.22: The pupil should put away the robe and bowl.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.23: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.24: He should not put away the bowl on the bare ground.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.25: When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe-rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.26: When the teacher has gotten up, the pupil should put away the seat and also the foot-stool, the foot-scraper, and the water for washing the feet.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.27: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.28: “If the teacher wants to bathe, the pupil should prepare the bath.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.29: If he wants a cold bath, he should prepare that;
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.30: if he wants a hot bath, he should prepare that.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.31: If the teacher wants to use the sauna, the pupil should knead bath powder, moisten the clay, take the sauna stool, and follow behind his teacher. After giving the teacher the sauna stool, receiving his robe, and putting it aside, he should give him the bath powder and the clay.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.32: If he’s able, he should enter the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.33: When entering the sauna, he should smear his face with clay, cover himself in front and behind, and then enter the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.34: He shouldn’t sit encroaching on the senior monks,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.35: and he shouldn’t block the junior monks from getting a seat.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.36: While in the sauna, he should do services for his teacher.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.37: When leaving the sauna, he should take the sauna stool, cover himself in front and behind, and then leave the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.38: He should also do services for his teacher in the water.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.39: When he has bathed, he should be the first to come out of the water. He should dry himself and put on his sarong. He should then wipe the water off his teacher’s body, and he should give him his sarong and then his upper robe. Taking the sauna stool, he should be first to return. He should prepare a seat, as well as set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.40: He should ask his teacher if he wants water to drink.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.41: If the teacher wants him to recite, he should do so.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.42: If the teacher wants to question him, he should be questioned.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.43: “If the dwelling where the teacher is staying is dirty, the pupil should clean it if he’s able.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.44: When he’s cleaning the dwelling, he should first take out the bowl and robe and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.45: He should take out the sitting mat and the sheet and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.46: He should take out the mattress and the pillow and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.47: Holding the bed low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.48: Holding the bench low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.49: He should take out the bed supports and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.50: He should take out the spittoon and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.51: He should take out the leaning board and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.52: After taking note of where it’s placed, he should take out the floor cover and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.53: If the dwelling has cobwebs, he should first remove them from the ceiling cloth, and he should then wipe the windows and the corners of the room.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.54: If the walls have been treated with red ocher and they’re moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the walls.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.55: If the floor has been treated with black and it’s moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the floor.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.56: If the floor is untreated, he should sprinkle it with water and then sweep it,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.57: while trying to avoid stirring up dust.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.58: He should look out for any trash and discard it.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.59: He should sun the floor cover, clean it, beat it, bring it back inside, and put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.60: He should sun the bed supports, wipe them, bring them back inside, and place them in the same position as before.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.61: He should sun the bed, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.62: He should sun the bench, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.63: He should sun the mattress and the pillow, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.64: He should sun the sitting mat and the sheet, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.65: He should sun the spittoon, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.66: He should sun the leaning board, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.67: He should put away the bowl and robe.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.68: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.69: He should not put away the bowl on the bare ground.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.70: When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe-rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.71: If dusty winds are blowing from the east, he should close the windows on the eastern side.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.72: If dusty winds are blowing from the west, he should close the windows on the western side.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.73: If dusty winds are blowing from the north, he should close the windows on the northern side.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.74: If dusty winds are blowing from the south, he should close the windows on the southern side.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.75: If the weather is cold, he should open the windows during the day and close them at night.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.76: If the weather is hot, he should close the windows during the day and open them at night.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.77: If the precincts are dirty, he should sweep them.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.78: If the gateway is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.79: If the assembly hall is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.80: If the water-boiling shed is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.81: If the restroom is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.82: If there is no water for drinking, he should set it out.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.83: If there is no water for washing, he should set it out.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.84: If there is no water in the rinsing pot, he should fill it.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.85: “If the teacher becomes discontent, the pupil should send him away or have him sent away, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.86: If the teacher becomes anxious, the pupil should dispel it or have it dispelled, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.87: If the teacher has a wrong view, the pupil should make him give it up or get someone else to do it, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.88: If the teacher has committed a heavy offense and deserves probation,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.89: the pupil should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.90: If the teacher has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be sent back to the beginning,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.91: the pupil should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.92: If the teacher has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be given the trial period,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.93: the pupil should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.94: If the teacher has committed a heavy offense and deserves rehabilitation,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.95: the pupil should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.96: If the Sangha wants to do a legal procedure against his teacher—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.97: the pupil should make an effort to stop it or to reduce the penalty.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.98: But if the Sangha has already done a legal procedure against his teacher—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.99: the pupil should help the teacher conduct himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and try for the Sangha to lift that procedure.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.100: “If the teacher’s robe needs washing, the pupil should do it himself,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.101: or he should make an effort to have it done.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.102: If the teacher needs a robe, the pupil should make one himself,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.103: or he should make an effort to have one made.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.104: If the teacher needs dye, the pupil should make it himself,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.105: or he should make an effort to have it made.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.106: If the teacher’s robe needs dyeing, the pupil should do it himself,
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.107: or he should make an effort to have it done.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.108: When he’s dyeing the robe, he should carefully and repeatedly turn it over, and he shouldn’t go away while it’s still dripping.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.109: Without asking permission of his teacher, he shouldn’t do any of the following: give away or receive a bowl;
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.117: or have work done by anyone;
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.119: or have a service done by anyone;
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.120: be the attendant monk for anyone
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.121: or take anyone as his attendant monk;
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.123: or have almsfood brought back by anyone;
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.124: enter the village, go to the charnel ground, or leave for another region.
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.125: If his teacher is sick, he should nurse him for as long as he lives, or he should wait until he has recovered.”
pli-tv-kd1:32.3.126: The proper conduct toward a teacher is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:33.1.31: “If the pupil wants to bathe, the teacher should prepare the bath.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.32: If he wants a cold bath, he should prepare that;
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.33: if he wants a hot bath, he should prepare that.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.34: If the pupil wants to use the sauna, the teacher should knead bath powder, moisten the clay, take the sauna stool, and go to the sauna. After giving the pupil the sauna stool, receiving his robe, and putting it aside, he should give him the bath powder and the clay.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.35: If he’s able, he should enter the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.36: When entering the sauna, he should smear his face with clay, cover himself in front and behind, and then enter the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.37: He shouldn’t sit encroaching on the senior monks, and he shouldn’t block the junior monks from getting a seat.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.38: While in the sauna, he should do services for his pupil.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.39: When leaving the sauna, he should take the sauna stool, cover himself in front and behind, and then leave the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.40: The teacher should also do services for his pupil in the water.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.41: When the teacher has bathed, he should be the first to come out of the water. He should dry himself and put on his sarong. He should then wipe the water off his pupil’s body, and he should give him his sarong and then his upper robe. Taking the sauna stool, he should be first to return. He should prepare a seat, as well as set out a foot-stool, a foot-scraper, and water for washing the feet.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.42: He should ask his pupil if he wants water to drink.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.43: “If the dwelling where the pupil is staying is dirty, the teacher should clean it if he’s able.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.44: When he’s cleaning the dwelling, he should first take out the bowl and robe and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.45: He should take out the sitting mat and the sheet and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.46: He should take out the mattress and the pillow and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.47: Holding the bed low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.48: Holding the bench low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.49: He should take out the bed supports and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.50: He should take out the spittoon and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.51: He should take out the leaning board and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.52: After taking note of where it’s placed, he should take out the floor cover and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.53: If the dwelling has cobwebs, he should first remove them from the ceiling cloth, and he should then wipe the windows and the corners of the room.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.54: If the walls have been treated with red ocher and they’re moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the walls.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.55: If the floor has been treated with black and it’s moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the floor.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.56: If the floor is untreated, he should sprinkle it with water and then sweep it,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.57: while trying to avoid stirring up dust.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.58: He should look out for any trash and discard it.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.59: He should sun the floor cover, clean it, beat it, bring it back inside, and put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.60: He should sun the bed supports, wipe them, bring them back inside, and place them in the same position as before.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.61: He should sun the bed, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.62: He should sun the bench, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back in the same place as before.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.63: He should sun the mattress and the pillow, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.64: He should sun the sitting mat and the sheet, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back the way they were.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.65: He should sun the spittoon, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.66: He should sun the leaning board, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.67: He should put away the bowl and robe.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.68: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.69: He should not put away the bowl on the bare ground.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.70: When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe-rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.71: If dusty winds are blowing from the east, he should close the windows on the eastern side.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.72: If dusty winds are blowing from the west, he should close the windows on the western side.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.73: If dusty winds are blowing from the north, he should close the windows on the northern side.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.74: If dusty winds are blowing from the south, he should close the windows on the southern side.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.75: If the weather is cold, he should open the windows during the day and close them at night.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.76: If the weather is hot, he should close the windows during the day and open them at night.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.77: If the precincts are dirty, he should sweep them.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.78: If the gateway is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.79: If the assembly hall is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.80: If the water-boiling shed is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.81: If the restroom is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.82: If there is no water for drinking, he should set it out.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.83: If there is no water for washing, he should set it out.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.84: If there is no water in the rinsing pot, he should fill it.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.85: “If the pupil becomes discontent, the teacher should send him away or have him sent away, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.86: If the pupil becomes anxious, the teacher should dispel it or have it dispelled, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.87: If the pupil has a wrong view, the teacher should make him give it up or get someone else to do it, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.88: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves probation,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.89: the teacher should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.90: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be sent back to the beginning,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.91: the teacher should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.92: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be given the trial period,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.93: the teacher should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.94: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves rehabilitation,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.95: the teacher should try for the Sangha to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.96: If the Sangha wants to do a legal procedure against his pupil—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.97: the teacher should make an effort to stop it or to reduce the penalty.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.98: But if the Sangha has already done a legal procedure against his pupil—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.99: the teacher should help the pupil conduct himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and try for the Sangha to lift that procedure.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.100: “If the pupil’s robe needs washing, the teacher should show him how to do it,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.101: or he should make an effort to have it done.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.102: If the pupil needs a robe, the teacher should show him how to make one,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.103: or he should make an effort to have one made.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.104: If the pupil needs dye, the teacher should show him how to make it,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.105: or he should make an effort to have it made.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.106: If the pupil’s robe needs dyeing, the teacher should show him how to do it,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.107: or he should make an effort to have it done.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.108: When he’s dyeing the robe, he should carefully and repeatedly turn it over, and he shouldn’t go away while it’s still dripping.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.109: If his pupil is sick, he should nurse him for as long as he lives, or he should wait until he has recovered.”
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.110: The proper conduct toward a pupil is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.111: The sixth section for recitation is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.1: On a later occasion the pupils did not conduct themselves properly toward their teachers. …
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.2: They told the Buddha. He had the monks gathered and said,
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.3: “A pupil should conduct himself properly toward his teacher.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.4: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.5: They still did not conduct themselves properly.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.6: They told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and said,
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.7: “You should dismiss one who doesn’t conduct himself properly.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.8: And this is how he should be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.9: If the teacher makes it understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech: ʻI dismiss you,’ or, ʻDon’t come back here,’ or, ʻRemove your bowl and robe,’ or, ʻYou shouldn’t attend on me’—
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.11: If he doesn’t make it understood by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then the pupil isn’t dismissed.”
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.12: Pupils who had been dismissed did not ask for forgiveness.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.15: They still did not ask for forgiveness.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.16: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.17: “One who has been dismissed should ask for forgiveness.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.18: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.19: Teachers who were asked for forgiveness did not forgive.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.23: The pupils left, disrobed, and joined the ascetics of other religions.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.24: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.25: “When asked for forgiveness, you should forgive.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.26: If you don’t, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.27: Teachers dismissed pupils who were conducting themselves properly and did not dismiss those who were not.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.28: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.29: “You should not dismiss someone who is conducting himself properly.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.30: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.31: And you should dismiss someone who isn’t conducting himself properly.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.32: If you don’t, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.33: “If a pupil has five qualities, he should be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.34: He doesn’t have much affection for his teacher; he doesn’t have much confidence in his teacher; he doesn’t have a strong sense of conscience in regard to his teacher; he doesn’t have much respect for his teacher; he hasn’t developed his mind much under his teacher.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.36: If a pupil has five qualities, he shouldn’t be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.37: He has much affection for his teacher; he has much confidence in his teacher; he has strong sense of conscience in regard to his teacher; he has much respect for his teacher; he has developed his mind much under his teacher.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.39: If a pupil has five qualities, he deserves to be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.40: He doesn’t have much affection for his teacher; he doesn’t have much confidence in his teacher; he doesn’t have a strong sense of conscience in regard to his teacher; he doesn’t have much respect for his teacher; he hasn’t developed his mind much under his teacher.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.42: If a pupil has five qualities, he doesn’t deserve to be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.43: He has much affection for his teacher; he has much confidence in his teacher; he has a strong sense of conscience in regard to his teacher; he has much respect for his teacher; he has developed his mind much under his teacher.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.45: If a pupil has five qualities, the teacher is at fault if he doesn’t dismiss him, but he’s not at fault if he dismisses him.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.46: The pupil doesn’t have much affection for his teacher; he doesn’t have much confidence in his teacher; he doesn’t have a strong sense of conscience in regard to his teacher; he doesn’t have much respect for his teacher; he hasn’t developed his mind much under his teacher.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.48: If a pupil has five qualities, the teacher is at fault if he dismisses him, but he’s not at fault if he doesn’t dismiss him.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.49: The pupil has much affection for his teacher; he has much confidence in his teacher; he has a strong sense of conscience in regard to his teacher; he has much respect for his teacher; he has developed his mind much under his teacher.”
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.51: Asking for forgiveness when dismissed is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.1: Soon afterwards, when they had ten years of seniority, ignorant and incompetent monks gave formal support.
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.2: As a result there were ignorant teachers with knowledgeable pupils,
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.6: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.7: “How can ignorant and incompetent monks give formal support, just because they have ten years of seniority?
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.8: There are ignorant teachers with knowledgeable pupils, incompetent teachers with competent pupils, uneducated teachers with learned pupils, stupid teachers with clever pupils.”
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.1: They told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.2: “Is it true, monks, that this is happening?”
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.8: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.9: “An ignorant and incompetent monk should not give formal support.
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.10: If he does, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.11: I allow a competent and capable monk to give formal support, if he has ten or more years of seniority.”
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.12: The section on the ignorant and incompetent is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.0: 22. Discussion of the ending of formal support
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.1: At that time there were preceptors and teachers who went away, disrobed, died, or joined another faction, but their pupils did not know about the ending of support.
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.3: “There are these five reasons why the formal support from a preceptor comes to an end:
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.4: the preceptor goes away; the preceptor disrobes; the preceptor dies; the preceptor joins another faction; or the preceptor gives an order.
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.6: There are these six reasons why the formal support from a teacher comes to an end:
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.7: the teacher goes away; the teacher disrobes; the teacher dies; the teacher joins another faction; the teacher gives an order; or one is reunited with one’s preceptor.”
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.9: The discussion of the ending of formal support is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:63.2.4: After getting up early one morning, that monk walked back and forth outside.
pli-tv-kd1:63.2.5: When the monk had left, the dragon relaxed and fell asleep,

pli-tv-kd1:63.3.1: Just then that monk decided to go back inside. When he opened the door, he saw the serpent filling the whole dwelling, and being terrified, he screamed.
pli-tv-kd1:63.3.2: Monks came running to and asked him,
pli-tv-kd1:63.3.5: The dragon woke up from the noise and sat down on his seat.
pli-tv-kd1:63.3.10: And the dragon told them what had happened.
pli-tv-kd1:63.4.1: He then had the Sangha of monks gathered and said to the dragon,
pli-tv-kd1:63.4.2: “You dragons are unable to make progress on this spiritual path.

pli-tv-kd1:63.5.1: And the Buddha addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:63.5.2: “There are two occasions when dragons appear in their own form:

pli-tv-kd1:63.5.5: Monks, an animal should not be given the full ordination. If it has been given, it should be expelled.”

pli-tv-kd1:66.1.1: On one occasion a number of monks were traveling from Sāketa to Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd1:66.1.2: As they were traveling, they were attacked by gangsters. Some of the monks were robbed and others were killed.
pli-tv-kd1:66.1.3: The King’s men came out from Sāvatthī. They caught some of the bandits, but others ran away.
pli-tv-kd1:66.1.4: Those who ran away went forth with the monks, but those who were caught were taken to be executed.

pli-tv-kd1:66.2.6: The monks then told the Buddha, who said,

pli-tv-kd1:72.1.0: 58. Formal support for those who are shameless
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.1: At that time the monks from the group of six gave formal support to those who were shameless.
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.2: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.3: “You should not give formal support to those who are shameless.
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.5: At that time monks lived with formal support from those who were shameless.
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.6: Soon they too became shameless and bad.
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.7: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.8: “You should not live with formal support from those who are shameless.
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.9: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.11: “The Buddha has laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.12: that one should not give formal support to those who are shameless and that one shouldn’t live with such support from those who are shameless.
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.13: But how do we know who is shameless and who is not?”
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.14: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:72.1.15: “I allow you to wait for four or five days to find out if the other person is compatible with the monks.”

pli-tv-kd1:73.4.2: and who was at ease in his dwelling.
pli-tv-kd1:73.4.4: “The Buddha has laid down a rule

pli-tv-kd1:73.4.8: “If you are staying in the wilderness and observe that you are at ease, and you are unable to obtain formal support, I allow you to live without.
pli-tv-kd1:73.4.9: But when a suitable support-giver comes, you should live with formal support from him.”
pli-tv-kd1:74.1.0: 60. The allowance to make proclamations using the clan name
pli-tv-kd1:74.1.1: At one time someone wanted the full ordination with Venerable Mahākassapa.
pli-tv-kd1:74.1.2: Mahākassapa sent a message to Venerable Ānanda:
pli-tv-kd1:74.1.3: “Please come, Ānanda, and do the proclamation.”
pli-tv-kd1:74.1.5: “Because I respect the elder so much, I’m unable to say his name.”
pli-tv-kd1:74.1.6: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:74.1.7: “I allow you to do the proclamation using clan name, too.”

pli-tv-kd1:75.1.0: 62. The allowance to be fully ordained when one is twenty years old since appearing in the womb
pli-tv-kd1:75.1.1: At that time Venerable Kumārakassapa had been given the full ordination twenty years after he appeared in the womb.
pli-tv-kd1:75.1.3: “The Buddha has laid down a rule
pli-tv-kd1:75.1.4: that a person less than twenty years old shouldn’t be given the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd1:75.1.5: I was ordained twenty years after being in the womb.
pli-tv-kd1:75.1.6: So, have I been ordained or not?”
pli-tv-kd1:75.1.7: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:75.1.8: “When the mind first appears in the mother’s womb, when the the consciousness first manifests, that is a person’s birth.
pli-tv-kd1:75.1.9: I allow you to give the full ordination to someone who is twenty years old since appearing in the womb.”
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.0: 63. The process for the full ordination
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.1: At that time the full ordination had been given to people who had leprosy, abscesses, mild leprosy, tuberculosis, and epilepsy.
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.2: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.3: “The one who is giving the full ordination should ask about the thirteen obstructions.
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.4: And it should be done like this:
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.5: ʻDo you have any of these diseases:
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.6: leprosy, abscesses, mild leprosy, tuberculosis, or epilepsy?
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.11: Are you employed by the King?
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.12: Do you have permission from your parents?
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.14: Do you have a full set of bowl and robes?
pli-tv-kd1:76.1.16: What is the name of your preceptor?’”
pli-tv-kd1:76.2.1: Soon afterwards they asked those seeking the full ordination about the obstructions without first instructing them.
pli-tv-kd1:76.2.2: They were embarrassed, humiliated, and unable to respond.
pli-tv-kd1:76.2.3: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:76.2.4: “You should instruct first and then ask about the obstructions.
pli-tv-kd1:76.3.1: They instructed them right there in the midst of the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd1:76.3.2: Once more those seeking the full ordination were embarrassed, humiliated, and unable to respond.
pli-tv-kd1:76.3.3: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:76.3.4: “You should instruct them to one side and then ask about the obstructions in the midst of the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd1:76.3.5: And it should be done like this.
pli-tv-kd1:76.3.6: First they should be told to choose a preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:76.3.7: Their bowl and robes should then be pointed out to them:
pli-tv-kd1:76.3.8: ʻThis is your bowl, this your outer robe, this your upper robe, and this your sarong.
pli-tv-kd1:76.3.9: Now please go and stand over there.’”
pli-tv-kd1:76.4.1: They were instructed by monks who were ignorant and incompetent.
pli-tv-kd1:76.4.2: And because they were badly instructed, they were once again embarrassed, humiliated, and unable to respond.

pli-tv-kd1:78.1.0: 65. The four things not to be done
pli-tv-kd1:78.1.1: On one occasion after giving the full ordination to someone, the monks left.
pli-tv-kd1:78.1.2: The newly ordained monk lagged behind, walking by himself. On the way he met his old wife.
pli-tv-kd1:78.1.6: “It’s difficult for those gone forth to get sex.
pli-tv-kd1:78.1.8: And he had intercourse with her.
pli-tv-kd1:78.1.9: It took him a long time to catch up with the other monks. They asked him
pli-tv-kd1:78.1.10: why it had taken him so long
pli-tv-kd1:78.2.1: and he told them what had happened.
pli-tv-kd1:78.2.2: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd1:78.2.3: “When you have given the full ordination to someone, you should give him a companion and point out the four things not to be done:
pli-tv-kd1:78.2.4: A monk who is fully ordained should not have sexual intercourse, even with an animal.
pli-tv-kd1:78.2.5: If he has sexual intercourse, he’s not an ascetic, not a son of the Sakyan.
pli-tv-kd1:78.2.6: Just as a man with his head cut off is unable to continue living by reconnecting it to the body,
pli-tv-kd1:78.2.7: so too a monk who has had sexual intercourse is not an ascetic, not a son of the Sakyan.
pli-tv-kd1:78.2.8: You shouldn’t do this for as long as you live.
pli-tv-kd1:78.3.1: A monk who is fully ordained should not steal, even a straw.
pli-tv-kd1:78.3.2: If he steals a pāda coin, the worth of a pāda, or more than a pāda, he’s not an ascetic, not a son of the Sakyan.
pli-tv-kd1:78.3.3: Just as a fallen, withered leaf is incapable of becoming green again,
pli-tv-kd1:78.3.4: so too a monk who, intending to steal, takes a pāda coin, the worth of a pāda, or more than a pāda, which had not been given to him, is not an ascetic, not a son of the Sakyan.
pli-tv-kd1:78.3.5: You shouldn’t do this for as long as you live.
pli-tv-kd1:78.4.1: A monk who is fully ordained should not intentionally kill a living being, even a small insect.
pli-tv-kd1:78.4.2: If he intentionally kills a human being, even just causing an abortion, he’s not an ascetic, not a son of the Sakyan.
pli-tv-kd1:78.4.3: Just as an ordinary stone that has broken in half cannot be put back together again,
pli-tv-kd1:78.4.4: so too a monk who has intentionally killed a human being is not an ascetic, not a son of the Sakyan.
pli-tv-kd1:78.4.5: You shouldn’t do this for as long as you live.
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.1: A monk who is fully ordained should not claim a superhuman quality, even just saying, ʻI delight in empty dwellings.’
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.2: If, because he has bad desires and is overcome by desire, he claims a non-existent, unreal superhuman quality—whether absorption, release, stillness, attainment, path, or fruit—he’s not an ascetic, not a son of the Sakyan.
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.3: Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth,
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.4: so too a monk with bad desires, overcome by desire, who has claimed a non-existent, unreal superhuman quality is not an ascetic, not a son of the Sakyan.
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.5: You shouldn’t do this for as long as you live.”
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.6: The four things not to be done are finished.
